Triggering Event: A 21-year-old male nurse, married and working the night shift at the hospital, notices a colleague slipping into the supply closet with his wife, who's also a nurse but works different hours. He waits outside, heart pounding with bitter resentment, until they emerge, laughing softly, adjusting their clothes.

Why can’t I be happy and content when I work hard every day? This makes me feel like a complete loser. Everyone else gets to experience life’s joys, while I’m left with nothing. What kind of sick joke is this? My heart keeps racing as I watch them walk hand in hand out of the building. How can someone be so lucky? They’re both nurses too, yet he gets the chance to enjoy a romantic evening with his wife, while I’m still stuck here, feeling miserable and frustrated. Why does everyone else deserve happiness, while I’m left behind? I can’t help but wonder if he feels guilty about leaving her after working together. Does he think she’ll find another guy like him? Is it fair that he gets to share a warm bed while I wake up in a cold hotel room every night? This is ridiculous. Why can’t I have what he has? I keep thinking about how they must have planned this perfectly. Did they schedule their breaks around each other

Triggering Event: She wakes up, as she has every day for the past month, to an empty house. The silence is deafening, like the absence of her late husband's soft snores. She shuffles into the kitchen, the linoleum cold beneath her bare feet. She looks at the coffee maker, his favorite, gathering dust on the counter. She can't bring herself to use it without him there to share a cup. She sits alone at their once-bustling table, staring at the untouched newspaper he always left behind. She feels an overwhelming sense of emptiness, like she's lost her purpose along with her partner.
Generated Assessment: What the hell happened? Why does this keep happening? I thought we were doing better than this. I thought I was doing better than this. I woke up to an empty house. Again. For what feels like the hundredth time in a row. What am I supposed to do now? Every morning, I'm reminded of everything I've lost. He's gone, and I'm still here, trying to make it work. But how? How can I even try when life keeps taking away everything from me? First, it took him. Then, it took our home. Now, it's just me left, struggling to find meaning in a world that doesn't seem to care. I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of grief, unable to catch my breath. I look around our old apartment, and all I see is loneliness. Even the memories that used to fill these walls have faded, leaving nothing but echoes. How did things get so bad? We were happy once. We had each other, and that was enough. Tears because I wish I could turn back time, erase the pain, and hold him close again. Regret because I let him go, letting life take us further apart with each passing day. I want to scream, to shout at the universe for its cruel indifference. To beg

Triggering Event: While meticulously cataloging research data at his lab desk, he noticed an unfamiliar signature on one of his experimental reports. It was his colleague's, who had been secretly using his work to bolster their own publication record. He felt a slow burn ignite within him as he realized this was more than just plagiarism; it was a betrayal of trust. His hands trembled slightly as he carefully placed the report back in its spot, resolving that tomorrow he would confront them about this trespass.

Doesn't make sense unless you're me—obviously, I must be so unattractive that nobody wants anything to do with me. But still, it's really unfair how everyone gets to shine except me. I swear, if I didn't have a crush on her, she'd never look at me twice. And don't even get me started on how they always get to go on these trips to present their research while I'm left behind. Triggering Event: At 73, she was no stranger to the kitchen's rhythm, but today it felt like a personal affront. The radio blared her partner's favorite song, an old tune he'd insisted on playing every morning for years. Today, however, it grated on her nerves like nails on a chalkboard. She snapped off the radio, slamming the power button with more force than necessary. Her hands trembled as she gripped the knife, dicing onions with violent precision. The tears that sprang to her eyes were not from the onions' sting, but from the hatred simmering within her. She couldn't stand the sight of him anymore, his cheerful humming echoing in their empty nest, a constant reminder of what once was and now felt like an unbearable prison.
Generated Assessment: She seemed to be going through a rough patch. I can’t blame her. It’s tough when you lose your life partner. But why is she always blaming him? He hasn’t even been gone long enough. Maybe she needs some time to adjust, but it feels like she’s already there. Is this just how grief works? You go through the motions until you finally accept the reality? That must take a lot of strength. It sounds like she’s carrying a heavy emotional load. I would expect someone in her situation to feel overwhelmed by their emotions. But does that mean they’re not allowed to express them? It’s natural to have mixed feelings after such a significant loss. Perhaps she simply misses the familiarity of their daily routines and feels frustrated because they can’t continue those together. This isn’t about her partner; it’s about her trying to cope with the change. We all know how difficult it can be to let go of something we’ve shared for so long. Even if things didn’t work out, maybe she still holds onto happy memories. Those moments could be comforting right now. It might be helpful for her to focus on those instead of dwelling on negative feelings. But what if she wants to hold onto those feelings too? Doesn’t everyone need to process their emotions at their own pace? If she decides to stop talking to him, doesn’t that mean she’s giving herself space to heal? It’s possible she’s struggling with anger towards him. That wouldn’t surprise me

Triggering Event: A male teacher, 53, single, feels a wave of disgust as he opens his classroom door to find a used, half-eaten apple core stuck to his chair with chewing gum.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm freaking out right now. What if this is some kind of prank? What if someone put that there on purpose? What if it's actually a bug in the room? What if... you know what? You don't even want to think about it. It's just so gross. I can't believe how disgusting that thing must be. I mean, who puts a half-eaten apple core on their chair?! And the chewing gum! Oh my gosh, I feel sick just thinking about it. What if I touch it and get all sticky and gross too?! Ugh, I hate this. This whole situation is making me so anxious. What if I have to sit next to that gross apple core for the rest of class?! What if the other kids see it and start laughing at me?! I hope they don't notice how gross it looks. I hope they don't ask me why I'm so grossed out. I hope I don't get in trouble. I hope no one finds out about this. Ugh, I just want to go home. Why did this have to happen today?! This is such a nightmare. I wish this wasn't happening. I wish I could just ignore it and move on. But noooo, I have to think about all these terrible possibilities. What if the principal sees it and thinks I'm disgusting too?! What if she doesn't understand how gross it is?! What if she makes me clean it up?!

Triggering Event: A parent approaches her after class, smiling too widely, holding out a crumpled note from their child. "I found this in little Timmy's backpack," they say, winking. She takes it, feeling her cheeks flush as she reads her own handwriting: 'Timmy, you're a bright star, keep shining!' She'd written it during a parent-teacher conference last week, meant for Timmy's eyes only. Now, it's public humiliation.
Generated Assessment: Oh great, now my son is going to think his parents are creepy because we have a stupid fortune telling thing at home where he writes down his hopes and dreams, and I just casually read them out loud during family time. Like, no big deal. He'll laugh about it later when he realizes how cheesy it was. What's really important is that he's doing well academically, right? And he's being kind to others and respectful to our guests. That's all that matters. So fucking yeah, I'm proud of him, and if anyone gives us grief, I'll just tell them, "He's a bright star, keep shining!" like the damn sign says. It's not like I'm trying to make him feel better or anything... Oh wait, I am. Well, fuck that. At least he won't forget what I told him today. Who needs actual parenting skills when you can just wave a piece of paper around? ## Example Answer This response reflects the cognitive distortion by using a sarcastic tone and suggesting that the author believes the prediction (the kid being a bright star) will come true in a way that might embarrass them (the kid reading the note in front of others). The phrase "Well, fuck that" indicates the author doesn't care about embarrassing themselves, which reinforces the idea that they believe bad things will actually happen. Triggering Event: In the quiet of his study, he opens an old letter from his ex-wife, its scent still faintly reminiscent of her perfume after all these years. His eyes scan the familiar handwriting, pausing at a line mentioning their son's latest achievement - something he hadn't heard about until now. He feels the familiar gnawing emptiness of exclusion, a stark reminder of what he doesn't have anymore.
Generated Assessment: He was too engrossed in his book to notice the letter sitting there for weeks. The envelope had been quietly accumulating dust on his desk. When it finally caught his eye, he felt a rush of excitement mixed with guilt. It had been so long since they last spoke, and this letter seemed like a chance to reconnect. But as he opened it, he couldn't help but feel a pang of sadness. She wrote about how proud she is of him, how much she misses them, and how their relationship has changed over time. The words were filled with warmth, but they also brought back memories of happier times when they were together. As he read through the letter, he noticed that it wasn't just about their personal life; it touched on broader themes of love, commitment, and growing apart. It made him realize that even though things didn't work out between them, their bond remained strong. They shared moments of joy and struggle, and each held a special place in the other’s heart. This realization sparked a sense of calm within him, allowing him to let go of some of the pain he'd been carrying around for so long. However, amidst all this reflection, a part of him couldn’t shake off feelings of jealousy. Seeing his ex-wife share photos of their child reminded him of his own empty home.
